    Marginal Structural Survival Models

    Robin Evans

    2025-07-18

    MSMs.Rmd

    Marginal Structural Models

    In this vignette we consider marginal structural models for time-to-event data. Begin by loading the library.

    library(survivl)
library(survival) # for coxph
options(digits=4)

    Then we define our formulas and family variables. We will have one baseline variable, and a single time-varying covariate, treatment and outcome. More specifically, let: \[\begin{align*} W &\sim \operatorname{Gamma}(1/2, \, 2) \\ Z_t \mid \overline{Z}_{t-1}, \overline{X}_{t-1} &\sim N(0.7 Z_{t-1} + 0.2 X_{t-1}, \, 1)\\ X_t \mid \overline{Z}_{t}, \overline{X}_{t-1} &\sim \operatorname{Bernoulli}(\operatorname{expit}(0.5 X_{t-1} + 0.25 Z_t))\\ P(Y_t = 1 \mid do(\overline{X}_{t}), W) &= \exp\{ - X_t + W/10\}, \end{align*}\] and assume that there is a Gaussian pair-copula linking \(Y_t\) with \(Z_{t-1},Z_t\), which also depends upon \(W\). We assume that the parameter for the \(Y_t\)-\(Z_{t-1}\) interaction is 0.2, and that for \(Y_t\)-\(Z_{t}\) given \(Z_{t-1}\) is 0.3.

    forms <- list(W ~ 1,
              Z ~ Z_l1 + X_l1,
              X ~ X_l1 + Z_l0,
              Y ~ W + X_l0,
              list(Y = list(Z ~ W)))
fams <- list(3, 1, 5, 3, c(1))
pars <- list(W = list(beta=0, phi=1/2),
             Z = list(beta=c(0,0.7,0.2), phi=1),
             X = list(beta=c(-0.5,0.25,0.5)),
             Y = list(beta=c(1,-1/10,1/5), phi=1),
             cop = list(Y=list(Z=list(beta=c(0.5, 0.0))))
)
link <- list("log", "identity", "logit", "log")
surv_model <- survivl_model(T = 10, formulas = forms, family = fams, pars = pars, link=link)

    We can now simulate \(n=10^4\) observations from the model over 10 time points.

    n <- 1e4
set.seed(124)
dat <- rmsm(n, surv_model)
datl <- surv_to_long(dat, lag=1)

    Checking the fit

    We can check that our simulation has the correct parametric distributions. We use a Kolmogorov-Smirnov test to check the distribution of \(W\), and then regressions to test the distributions of the \(Z\)s and \(X\)s.

    ks.test(dat$W, "pgamma", scale=1/2, shape=2)
    ## 
##  Asymptotic one-sample Kolmogorov-Smirnov test
## 
## data:  dat$W
## D = 0.0072, p-value = 0.7
## alternative hypothesis: two-sided
    summary(glm(Z ~ W + Z_l1 + X_l1, data=datl))$coefficients
    ##              Estimate Std. Error  t value  Pr(>|t|)
## (Intercept) -0.005016   0.013589  -0.3691 7.120e-01
## W           -0.001837   0.010284  -0.1786 8.582e-01
## Z_l1         0.697434   0.005762 121.0411 0.000e+00
## X_l1         0.212808   0.014288  14.8941 6.393e-50
    summary(glm(X ~ X_l1 + Z, data=datl, family=binomial))$coefficients
    ##             Estimate Std. Error z value   Pr(>|z|)
## (Intercept)  -0.5162    0.02048 -25.202 3.804e-140
## X_l1          0.2726    0.02958   9.217  3.046e-20
## Z             0.4993    0.01215  41.088  0.000e+00

    Indeed, each of these variables is consistent with the parameters we used. For the survival outcome, we can use inverse probability weighting. The ipw package can estimate ipw weights for time varying confounders like Z.

    library(ipw)
temp <- ipwtm(
  X,
  family = "binomial",
  link = "logit",
  numerator = ~1,
  denominator = ~ Z,
  id = id,
  type = "all",
  timevar = t,
  data = datl,
)
datl$wt <- temp$ipw.weights
mod_correct <- coxph(Surv(t, t_stop, Y) ~ W + X, weights = wt, data = datl,
                     timefix = FALSE)
mod_naive <- coxph(Surv(t, t_stop, Y) ~ W + X, weights = rep(1, nrow(datl)), data = datl,
                   timefix = FALSE)
    tab_correct <- cbind(pars$Y$beta[-c(1)], -mod_correct$coef, summary(mod_correct)$coef[,-c(1,3)])
tab_correct[,4] <- pt(abs((tab_correct[,2]-tab_correct[,1])/tab_correct[,3]), df=n-4, lower.tail = FALSE)
tab_naive <- cbind(pars$Y$beta[-c(1)], -mod_naive$coef, summary(mod_naive)$coef[,-c(1,3)])
tab_naive[,4] <- pt(abs((tab_naive[,2]-tab_naive[,1])/tab_naive[,3]), df=n-4, lower.tail = FALSE)
library(kableExtra)
kableExtra::kbl(tab_naive, digits = c(2,3,5,2), booktabs=TRUE, format="latex")  %>%  
  kableExtra::add_header_above(c("Coef","Truth","Est.", "Std. Err.", "p-value"))
    kableExtra::kbl(tab_correct, digits = c(2,3,5,2), booktabs=TRUE, format="latex")  %>%  
  kableExtra::add_header_above(c("Coef","Truth","Est.", "Std. Err.", "p-value"))

    Multiple time-varying covariates

    We may well be interested in simulating more than one time-varying covariate. A new update allows us to update our surv_model object without redefining it.

    forms2 <- forms
forms2[[2]] <- list(Z1 ~ Z1_l1 + Z2_l1 + X_l1, 
                    Z2 ~ Z2_l1 + X_l1 + Z1_l0)
forms2[[3]] <- X ~ W + Z1_l0 + Z2_l0
fams2 <- fams
fams2[[2]] <- c(1,1)
pars2 <- pars
pars2 <- c(pars2,
           list(Z1 = list(beta=c(0,0.7,0.3,0.2), phi=1),
                Z2 = list(beta=c(0,0.5,0.2,0.1), phi=1)))
pars2$X <- list(beta = c(0,0.25,0.1,0.3))
link[[2]] <- rep("identity", 2)

    … and then by modifying the elements relating to the copula.

    forms2[[5]] <- list(Y = list(Z1 ~ W, Z2 ~ W))
fams2[[5]] <- list(c(1, 1))
pars2$cop <- list(Y=list(Z1=list(beta=c(0.5,0.2)),
                         Z2=list(beta=c(0.25,0))))
# should be able to just use modify
surv_model2 <- modify.survivl_model(surv_model, formulas = forms2,
                                    family = fams2,
                                    pars = pars2, link = link)

    We can then simulate as before.

    dat2 <-  rmsm(n, surv_model2)
dat2l <- surv_to_long(dat2, lag = 1)

    Checking the distributions, these all seem fine.

    summary(glm(Z1 ~ W + Z1_l1 + Z2_l1 + X_l1, data=dat2l))$coef
summary(glm(Z2 ~ W + Z2_l1 + X_l1 + Z1, data=dat2l))$coef
summary(glm(X ~ W + Z1 + Z2, data=dat2l, family=binomial))$coef

    For the outcome, we again apply IPW, and obtain:

    temp <- ipwtm(
  exposure = X,
  family = "binomial",
  link = "logit",
  numerator = ~W,
  denominator = ~Z1 + Z2 + X_l1,
  id = id,
  timevar = t,
  type = "all",
  data = dat2l
)
dat2l$wt <- temp$ipw.weights

mod_correct <- coxph(Surv(t, t_stop, Y) ~ W + X,  weights = dat2l$wt,
                     data = dat2l, timefix = FALSE)
mod_naive <- coxph(Surv(t, t_stop, Y) ~ W + X, weights = rep(1, nrow(dat2l)),
                     data = dat2l, timefix = FALSE)
    tab_correct <- cbind(pars$Y$beta[-c(1)], -mod_correct$coef, summary(mod_correct)$coef[,-c(1,3)])
tab_correct[,4] <- pt(abs((tab_correct[,2]-tab_correct[,1])/tab_correct[,3]), df=n-4, lower.tail = FALSE)
tab_naive <- cbind(pars$Y$beta[-c(1)], -mod_naive$coef, summary(mod_naive)$coef[,-c(1,3)])
tab_naive[,4] <- pt(abs((tab_naive[,2]-tab_naive[,1])/tab_naive[,3]), df=n-4, lower.tail = FALSE)
library(kableExtra)
kableExtra::kbl(tab_naive, digits = c(2,3,5,2), booktabs=TRUE, format="latex")  %>%  
  kableExtra::add_header_above(c("Coef","Truth","Est.", "Std. Err.", "p-value"))
    kableExtra::kbl(tab_correct, digits = c(2,3,5,2), booktabs=TRUE, format="latex")  %>%  
  kableExtra::add_header_above(c("Coef","Truth","Est.", "Std. Err.", "p-value"))
